utterances: I'm Neal Conan.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
`It is a moment pregnant with hope, but also fraught with peril.
That's how one of the UN's chief Middle East coordinators described the evacuation of Israeli settlements in Gaza and the northern West Bank which began today.
The pullout ranks as one of the most significant changes in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict since 1967.
Tens of thousands of Israelis rallied in Jerusalem on Friday to protest the pullout.
You're invited to join us today with questions about what makes this so important.
Will Israelis maintain their military post?
Who controls the border?
How might this affect US involvement in the peace process?
The e-mail address is totn@npr.org.
Well, I think that, in a sense, both sides benefit.
Even though it wasn't negotiated, at least the potential is both sides do.

First, in the case of the Palestinians, understand that Gaza has the greatest population density in the world, and the Israelis, to protect the settlements and the settlers, have controlled about 25 percent of the territory.
So when the Israelis get out of that, that means you're opening up one-quarter of the territory of Gaza that has been off limits to Palestinians, and that's a major benefit just in terms of space.
Also now that the greenhouses and the dairy farm have been bought for Palestinians, it'll be--the Palestinian Authority will own it, but it will probably lease it out to Palestinian business.
This can provide additional employment which is desperately needed in Gaza, and it also reflects what are thriving businesses.
So from a practical, psychological, physical standpoint, the Palestinians benefit.
From an economic standpoint, they can also benefit.

Israelis also benefit, though, because even though it's been very painful for the Israelis who have lived there, one of the issues that was raised that actually created a spur to getting out was not just the demographic question, which is important because of its trends, but also in places like Netzarim, you had 400 Israeli soldiers to protect 60 families there.
There was an illogic of having large numbers of soldiers protecting small numbers of families.
So from the standpoint of Israel's overall security posture, I think it's pretty clear that they're in a better position after being out of Gaza than they are while being in it.
Shibley Telhami, who benefits?
No question that both sides have some benefits out of this.
I think you can argue that the Israelis certainly benefit a lot economically, militarily.
Many Israelis felt that the Gaza settlements were a drain on Israel.
Some even wished that they would negotiated away already in Oslo even though the Israelis, in principle, didn't want to make that concession early on as part of final settlement.
And a lot of Israelis had felt that, you know, just to protect a little over 8,000 settlers, they were spending so much money and energy and lives.
So they benefit, no question.
I think the separation from both scenes would help them.
The Palestinians will have almost an end to the Israeli occupation.
I say `almost an end' because it doesn't end until you have a state really and access to the outside world 'cause they remain dependent on Israel.
But they benefit in that way; they have a new opportunity.
I think, unfortunately, a lot of other groups benefit.
Hamas benefits.
Hamas benefits because it does have an ability to claim that it forced Israel out.
It does benefit because it now has really kind of a new competition opened up in Gaza in which the Palestinian Authority is weak and they have a chance to advance.
What are the risks?
And there are enormous risks, one of which is what I call the gap of expectations.
I think each side is expecting this withdrawal to lead to something else, and I think that is going to become a problem as they both turn to their domestic politics in the months ahead.

The Palestinians and the Israelis will be, in essence, trying to put their political house in order at home, and that's going to escalate the rhetorical game and make them take harder lines than in the past on final status issues at a time when there is a different interpretation of the timetable at least of when the negotiations will start over final status questions and what is the timetable of a Palestinian state if at all in the coming months.
Here's a question.
It's sort of about what happens next.

This is from Walid Hasboon(ph): `Does Article 49 of the fourth Geneva Convention apply to the remaining settlements in the West Bank, which would mean all settlements and many other Israeli occupation practices are illegal?
Moreover, does this engagement mean that Israel is now in compliance with Article 49 as related to Gaza?
Dennis Ross.
Well, with regard to Gaza, the Israelis will be out.
So they are no longer an occupying power.
The Geneva Convention relates to the use of the occupying power and the responsibility the occupying power has.
Mm-hmm.
Israel will still be the, quote, ""occupying power"" in the West Bank, so the Geneva Convention would still apply there.
And--well, what about the West Bank?

If it's proved so difficult and so fractious, so divisive to the country of Israel to order these withdrawals from Gaza, which are presumably easier than some of the other more difficult areas in the West Bank, what does that say about the prospect of withdrawal from the West Bank?
Well, again, let's put this in some perspective.
Number one, there's no question that from the standpoint of the settlers, the settlers want to be raising the emotional cost of the withdrawal.
I don't believe you're going to see violence; there could be some isolated episodes of it.
I don't think you'll see violence because this is a citizen army on the Israeli side.
Violence against the Israeli army will create a terrible backlash in the Israeli public against the settlers.
So settler leaders don't want there to be violence.
There may be younger people highly ideologically motivated who may see things a little differently, but for the most part, I don't think we'll see violence.
So I think, number one, yes, the settlers want to create an emotional reality that makes it difficult to apply this precedent to the West Bank.
On the other hand, I go back to where I started.
The Israeli public will be watching; the whole world will be watching.

If Palestinians are able to overcome their own differences, if the rivalry between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority and Fatah is something that can be somehow managed so that, in a sense, there's a common approach to what happens not only during the period of withdrawal but in the next couple of months so that, in fact, we see the calm preserved, we don't see violence erupt--if that's the case, then it seems to me that you begin to demonstrate that there's a model that does work.
It's a model where the Palestinians, when they assume governance for themselves, they really do assume responsibility.
Hmm.
What's the action in the novel, Peggy?
When we see manifestations of Palestinian responsibility in one place, it may well be easier to sell it in another place.

From that standpoint, though this is bound to be very difficult--and we shouldn't underestimate the emotional trauma it's going to cause within Israel--I don't think it's the end of the road if, in fact, it ends up being managed well.
Mm-hmm.
Now the real question--and Shibley was raising this--is management not only right now but over time.
One of the things that has made me uneasy has been that the--what I call the security-for-access nexus.
The Israelis want security after they're out of Gaza; the Palestinians want free, unencumbered access into and out of Gaza.
If the security arrangements...
Air routes, seaports, that sort of...
That's right, and over land...
And over land from Egypt.
...so there isn't smuggling including into Israel and into the West Bank, because the main market for Gaza economically is the West Bank and vice versa, so they want practical links there.
Now the crossing points, the passages, the practical links--all of these issues have partial agreements; there isn't one in which there is a fully understanding right now.
And the problem that I see is that once the Israelis get out completely, when you begin to implement the arrangements, they're going to be implemented only after the Israelis are out.
And at that point, I can tell you knowing something about them, they're all complicated.
Well...

Complicated arrangements never go simply, and the net effect of that is you will end up refining them after the Israelis are out, which means when there's a problem, the Israelis will put a squeeze on the access.
If I may, let me just look at it from a slightly different angle.
I mean, I agree with Dennis on the necessity of Palestinians doing all they can to put their political and economic house in order to make the best of this an opportunity.
And I think we have a huge challenge, and I'm not--you know--and I'm not entirely sure is going to work out exactly as we all hope.
But let's assume it does and let's hope that it does.

If you're looking at it from the point of view of the Israelis, this was a unilateral withdrawal to minimize the number of attacks on Israel to bring about a level of relative security, to postpone final status issues.

If, in fact, there is a withdrawal and Sharon manages to regain the upper hand in Likud, he's a popular man overall because he will have managed to pull this off, withdrawal from Gaza, increasing security and maintaining the support of the US, getting even Arab countries and, to some extent, the Palestinian Authority to indirectly cooperate with him in the withdrawal.
He doesn't want to move to final status negotiations; he doesn't want to deal with those difficult issues.

The Israeli public--if the Palestinians are peaceful and they have their Gaza corner, what's the incentive for the Israeli public to push a prime minister of Israel who's not inclined to move in that direction?
What's the incentive for them to move him in that direction?
Why wouldn't they just sit comfortably and say--when he argues to them, `I've done this all on my own.
This is what I want to do'?
And I don't see where the incentive is going to come, Dennis.
Maybe you could tell me how this is going to generate some kind of public sentiment that would push it forward.
And briefly, if you would.
All right.
Look, we have to understand the context.
There is going to be pressure within Israel to do nothing until the next Israeli election.
Sharon is going to ...(unintelligible) until that election, which will probably be in the spring.
On the Palestinian side, obviously, this is a gap in expectations because Abu Mazen's going to want to be able to demonstrate that it was Gaza first and not Gaza last.
So the first thing's first.
You're going to have to be able to create a bridge that gets you through to the next elections.
I think that the Israeli public as a whole knows you can't just do Gaza and nothing else.

So the question is not about what happens between now and the Israeli election in terms of permanent status; the question is: What is the political process that's going to be in the aftermath of the next Israeli election, and how do you build a bridge to that point so that everything doesn't fall apart in between when you have a crisis over the gap in expectations?
I believe in the end, the Israeli public if they see that there's calm, they're going to understand that, `All right.
We still have a demographic problem.
We're still going to have to sort that out.
And let's--if we actually have a partner now, then let's pursue that pathway.
If we don't have a partner, there'll be no pressure.'
As we mentioned, some settlers vow to defy authorities until the last minute.
Some have already been moving in accordance with the disengagement plan, particularly those who live in the northern part of the Gaza Strip.
Joseph Ayalon is a lifeguard who lived in the northern settlement of Dugit for 15 years.
Yesterday, he moved from his home there, and he joins us now by phone from his new home in Nativ Ha'asara.
I hope I'm pronouncing that correctly.
Nice of you to join us today.
Hello.
Nativ Ha'asara.
OK.
Thanks very much for that.
Knowing how many people were--why did you decide to leave?
I not decide to leave.
Our prime minister, Ariel Sharon, he is the government, and the government decided to just move us out of Gaza.
Yet, as you know, other people are planning to resist, at least till the last moment.
You decided to move ahead.
Sorry.
I don't understand.
So why did you decide to leave earlier...
Oh, yeah.
...than some of your neighbors...
At age 17, Roach got a call for one of the biggest gigs a musician could get.
Duke Ellington's drummer had suddenly fallen ill.
Max would take his place.
Yeah.
It's just because we don't want any problems with the army, any argues, any fighting, you know.
We are in the northern territory of Gaza.
We decided to not develop any problems, and conflict with the soldiers.
This is the reason that we left
It must have been difficult, nevertheless, to leave the place you'd lived for so long.
Yes.
That's right.
What were your emotions as you left for the last time?
